title: 'He want to work anyway', is this sentence right? - Quora

response.answer_text: No, the sentence is incorrect. We have discussed this on Quora a NUMBER of times. I think you should often go through English grammar answers on Quora - and you'll get the answer even before you ask. Third person Singular (He/She/It) goes with an - s suffix verb in the PRESENT TENSE. Thus: Third pers. Sing. + verb+s. He/she/it work+s > He works, She works, It works. He sleeps, She sleeps, It sleeps. He plays, She plays, It plays. He goes, She goes, It goes. He drives, She drives, It drives. He supplies (books/food), She supplies (books/food), It (The van, for ex.) supplies (books/food). Note that after an ‘-o’ ending verb (go, do) and after a verb that ends in ‘consonant +y’ (supply imply, carry, party), spelling rules apply in accordance with rules of English spelling. No changes occur for the past tense, regardless of person (1st, 2nd, 3rd), or number (singular plural). Thus: I drove /slept /cooked/walked You drove/ slept/cooked… He/She/It drove /walked… They slept/cooked… We cooked/drove… Thus, your sentence should be either: He wants to work anyway (present /future) OR: He wanted to work anyway (past).

No, and there are two possible ways to correct the sentence depending on what you mean. 1. “He went to work anyway" as in “He didn't feel well, but he went to work anyway". This means that he did go to work despite feeling unwell. 2. “He wants to work anyway" as in “He didn't feel well but he wants to work anyway".This means that he still has the desire to work despite not being well.
No not at all. It should be:- He wants to work anyway. Because “HE” is third person singular & with it we use s/es in positive sentences.
